metadata.address: 34 Rupert St, Soho, London W1D 6DN, UK
metadata.name: The Palomar
metadata.description: The Palomar, Rupert Street, London, United Kingdom

reviews.text: Called months ago to make a reservation since we are not from London and wanted to eat here for my husband's birthday.  I  was told to wait until 60 days. I emailed promptly 60 days prior (at 10:00 a.m.) since the site would not let me book and was told they were fully booked. They gave me a list of other restaurants to eat at. Disappointing attitude.  Will surely eat where my business is welcome and appreciated.
Great food. Good vibe. The layout of the kitchen area does a good job of connecting you to the chefs and your food. Pricey, but as expected.

Brilliant night sitting at the bar/kitchen top. Food is delicious and the head chef is very loud, energetic and entertaining - dont go there for a calming experience! 
Waited for 2h to get in but the guy managing the list was very good at updating us while we had a drink elsewhere - well worth the wait.

I liked the ambience in The Palomar. It's entertaining to eat at the bar watching cooks preparing your food. Service is quick and friendly. The place seems to be popular as there was a queue outside to get in at 10PM when we were leaving. The middle eastern food however was a mixed bag, some dishes were good, some not so. I liked the salads and octopus with chickpea mash. Jerusalem Mix was a bit of a hoax though, the plate full of fried onions and couple of pieces of chicken liver buried underneath it. £14.5 dish with no much food on the plate...
Great place to eat and nice friendly and very helpful staff. If don’t have a booking it’s worth the wait. Uncomfortable to seat and eat on a high chair around the bar but definitely worth the shot.
If you like an interesting take on middle eastern food and specialty cocktail/mocktails head here. Friendly service. Gets really crowded so reservations recommended.
Very nice food and great for sharing but I suggest only getting one meat dish as they're very intensely flavoured and heavy
If you don't book, count a 1 or 1.5 hour wait. Polenta, octo-hummus and kubaneh were amazing. Jerusalem mess for dessert is a must!
We came on their opening Saturday and I was probably the best meal out we've ever had. Simply brilliant, buzzy and tasty
Just go and eat everything. It is packed but servers are super nice and very well versed in all the great eats.
Amazing food, tried 10 menu  itens and all were tasty! The Cauliflower steak and Seared Scallops are to die for!

review_article.summary: The 'Yiddish-style' chopped chicken liver pate, the Jerusalem-style polenta and the 'octo-hummus' are all fantastic, but portions are smallish, so you'll need to share.
It's Jerusalem meets Palestine meets Beirut meets a bonkers scenester vibe at this mad-as-a-hatter Israeli/Arab funky food party zone off Shaftesbury Avenue.
It's Jerusalem meets Palestine meets Beirut meets a bonkers scenester vibe at this Arab-Israeli funky food party zone.
This is where you'll find "fantastic Middle-Eastern inflected dishes," according to Jeremy Lee, chef and co-owner of London's Quo Vadis.
Pulse-quickening dance music, free-flowing drink, vibrantly flavoured dishes.
A hip slice of modern-day Jerusalem in the heart of theatreland, with a zinc kitchen counter running back to an intimate wood-panelled dining room.
This spot just off London's heaving Shaftsbury Avenue offers an authentically buzzing atmosphere paired with even better food.
Modern-day Jerusalem meets Japanese techniques and North African flavors at this Chinatown Eclectic with a 1930s vibe.
It pulls on the traditions of the Mediterranean fringes without being overwhelmed by them, and it does so with a vigour and enthusiasm which are so utterly infectious.
Palomar is a great restaurant throughout, but the almost all of this fun happens at the bar.

reviews.text: The Palomar Restaurant was our last stop in during our trip in London, and it turned out to be the perfect choice. This is definitely one of those...
This is both one of the hottest and controversial Restos for middle eastern food. Barbary its slightly wallet friendlier sister resto seems to generate more...
Put my name down for two at 6:30pm and was seated at 7:10pm (they estimated 8pm). I waited outside but they took my number down in case I wanted to walk...
Brilliant, bold flavors without any gimmicks. Rustic and hearty fare with a light touch. Desserts were divine. If this is what food tastes l...
Lovely lunch at The Palomar. The food is good with some items better than others. The bread was the highlight of the meal but at £6 each I ...
The best meal I've had in London, perhaps in the past year. Everything was amazing. My favorites were the beet carpaccio, octo-hummous, and ...
Could not fault a thing with this place. I loved everything. I wish I could eat their burnt aubergine everyday. And the lamb... oh the lamb....
Kubaneh bread is a must to order. The bread is very soft and full of smell and taste. Everything was well seasoned and delicious. Definitely...
